title: 108_hr3617
content: The "Presidential Funding Act of 2003" is the short title of this Act. It includes revisions to the system of presidential primary matching payments. The "Presidential Funding Act of 2003" amends the Internal Revenue Code to increase the matching rate for payments and adjust eligibility requirements, including raising the aggregate contributions per state to $15,000 and adding new participation criteria for candidates nominated by a political party. The Presidential Funding Act of 2003 increases the matching rate for payments and adjusts eligibility requirements for candidates nominated by a political party. This includes raising aggregate contributions per state to $15,000 and adding new participation criteria. Additionally, the act amends the period of availability of payments and increases the limitation on the total amount of payments. SEC. 3 amends the Internal Revenue Code to require candidates to participate in the primary payment system to be eligible for general election payments. Major and minor party candidates must have received payments for the nomination campaign. SEC. 4 revises candidate expenditure limits. Increase in coordinated party expenditures limit from 2 cents to 4 cents. Increase in expenditure limits for participating candidates to $75,000,000 for nomination and election campaigns, eliminating state-specific limits. Conforming amendment made to timing of cost-of-living adjustment. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to make conforming amendments related to the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971, including changes to subsections and clauses for calendar year 2004. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is being amended to include section 315(b)(1) and repeal the exclusion of fundraising costs from treatment as expenditures. Additionally, there is an increase in expenditure limits for primary candidates participating in the primary payment system who face certain nonparticipating opponents. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase expenditure limits for primary candidates facing nonparticipating opponents who exceed certain contribution thresholds. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase expenditure limits for primary candidates facing nonparticipating opponents who exceed certain contribution thresholds. Nonparticipating primary candidates exceeding 133 percent of the expenditure limitation must notify the Commission and opponents within 24 hours. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase expenditure limits for primary candidates facing nonparticipating opponents who exceed certain contribution thresholds. Candidates cannot receive additional payments once their total payments and contributions exceed the expenditure limit for a presidential campaign. SEC. 5. REVISIONS TO DESIGNATION OF INCOME TAX PAYMENTS BY INDIVIDUAL TAXPAYERS. Section 6096(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the designated amounts. The first sentence changes from "$3" to "$6" and the second sentence changes from "$6" to "$12" and from "$3" to "$6". Additionally, a new subsection is added for indexing the designated amounts after 2004, with adjustments made based on a percent difference. The text discusses amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding designated amounts and ensuring tax preparation software does not automatically respond to designation questions. Regulations will be promulgated to prevent automatic responses in electronic software for individual income tax returns. The Federal Election Commission will conduct a public information program to educate the public on the Presidential Election Campaign Fund, payment designation procedures, and the impact on taxpayers' income tax liability. Funds from the Campaign Fund will be used for this program. The Commission will conduct a public information program to educate the public on the Presidential Election Campaign Fund, with a maximum budget of $10,000,000 per Presidential election cycle. SEC. 6. ADDITIONAL GENERAL ELECTION PAYMENTS TO PARTICIPATING CANDIDATES FACING CERTAIN NONPARTICIPATING OPPONENTS. Section 9004(a)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to provide additional payments to eligible candidates of a major party in a presidential election who face opponents not eligible for payments under certain conditions. The Election Campaign Act of 1971 ensures equal payments under section 9006 for eligible candidates, including minor party candidates in presidential elections with opponents not eligible for payments under the same section. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 allows candidates to receive equal payments under section 9006 if their contributions or expenditures exceed certain limits. Amendments to section 9005 outline special rules for determining eligibility for additional payments. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 allows candidates to receive equal payments under section 9006 if their contributions or expenditures exceed certain limits. Special rules for certification of eligibility for additional payments include reporting expenditures by ineligible candidates and certification requirements within 24 hours. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 allows candidates to receive equal payments under section 9006 if their contributions or expenditures exceed certain limits. Certification requirements for additional payments include reporting expenditures by ineligible candidates and prompt certification to the Secretary of the Treasury for payment. Amendments are made to ensure exclusion of additional payments from determination of expenditure limits. Amendments are made to the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to reduce candidate expenditures by the amount of any additional payment received under section 9004(a)(1)(B) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. SEC. 7 amends the Internal Revenue Code to determine amounts in the Presidential Election Campaign Fund based on estimated deposits. SEC. 8 repeals the priority use of funds for political conventions. SEC. 8 repeals the priority use of funds for political conventions, limiting the amount deposited to what is available after other payments are made. SEC. 9 states that these changes apply to elections after January 1, 2005.
